case_facts:
The case involved Millin A. Nobregas (plaintiff) and Virginia Hadad Gonzalez (defendant). From approximately May 2007 through June 2008, Nobregas attended weekly mental health counseling sessions with Gonzalez at her home, paying $60 per session. Gonzalez claimed to have a medical doctorate degree and provided counseling services to Nobregas, who was an attorney and sought counseling on the recommendation of a mutual friend and his ex-girlfriend. Documentation from the Florida Department of Health later issued a Cease and Desist notice to Gonzalez on August 8, 2013, and the Florida Certification Board's records were requested as part of the proceedings.

The relationship became contentious when Gonzalez began counseling Nobregas's ex-girlfriend, Veronica Fazzio, who was the mother of his child. Nobregas alleged that Gonzalez disclosed confidential information from his counseling sessions, while Gonzalez maintained that any information she received either came from third parties or was disclosed in the presence of others. In July 2012, Gonzalez filed a child abuse complaint against Nobregas with the Florida Department of Children and Families, which was dismissed. She also filed a Florida Bar complaint against him alleging assault after her deposition, which was also dismissed.

Nobregas sued Gonzalez for fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, invasion of privacy, negligence, and violation of Florida's Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act. He sought damages for emotional distress, damage to his reputation, interference with his parental rights, and legal defense costs. Medical experts, including Dr. Mark Barnett (psychiatrist) and Dr. Adriana Rosen (Ph.D.), were prepared to testify about Nobregas's mental condition and how Gonzalez's actions caused and aggravated his condition, including the need for new medication. Gonzalez denied most allegations in her answer and raised multiple affirmative defenses, including that Nobregas had given permission to disclose information, that she was privileged to make any alleged disclosures, and that Nobregas's claims should be barred due to unclean hands.

raw_texts: COUNT I - ACTION FOR SEVERE INFLICTION OF EMOTIONAL DISTRESS

compensatory: damages greater than $15,000.00 exclusive of interest, attorney fees and costs
monetary damages
damages from privacy breach and disclosure of confidential information
damages for mental pain
damages for increased anxiety, mental anguish, and pain and suffering
damages from defending ongoing paternity action
loss of monies paid to defendant for counseling services
actual damages
statutory: damages under Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act (FDUTPA)
equitable: declaratory judgment that defendant violated FDUTPA
injunction enjoining future violations of FDUTPA
other: such other relief that the Court deems just and proper

defenses.name: Failure to Meet Conditions Precedent
defenses.raw_text: FIRST AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Plaintiff has failed to meet all conditions precedent in bringing these actions. As such, the Plaintiff's action is barred.

defenses.name: Waiver of Confidentiality
defenses.raw_text: SECOND AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Plaintiff shared information with third parties, including the mother of Plaintiff's child and Plaintiff's girlfriend, therefore he waived any right to confidentiality. As a result, Plaintiff's claims are barred.

defenses.name: Qualified Immunity
defenses.raw_text: THIRD AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Any disclosures of confidential information made by Defendant were made with qualified immunity because it is permissible to disclose information to protect a child or for a bar complaint. As a result, Plaintiff's claims are barred.

defenses.name: Privileged Communication
defenses.raw_text: FOURTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Defendant was privileged to make any alleged disclosures. As a result, Plaintiff's claims are barred.

defenses.name: Unclean Hands
defenses.raw_text: FIFTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Plaintiff cannot seek damages or equity because the Plaintiff comes to the Court with unclean hands. As a result, Plaintiff's claims are barred.

defenses.name: Justification
defenses.raw_text: SIXTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Defendant was justified in making any alleged disclosures. As a result, Plaintiff's claims are barred.

defenses.name: No Confidential Information
defenses.raw_text: EIGHTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Defendant never received any confidential information from Plaintiff. Therefore, Plaintiff's claims ought to be barred.

defenses.name: Consent to Disclosure
defenses.raw_text: NINTH AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE - Plaintiff gave Defendant permission to disclose confidential information. Therefore, Plaintiff's claims ought to be barred.

raw_texts: COUNT II- ACTION FOR FRAUD OR FRAUDULENT MISREPRESENTATION

compensatory: monetary damages for FDUTPA violation
damages for increased anxiety, mental anguish, and pain and suffering
damages for mental pain, disturbance of peace of mind and privacy
damages greater than $15,000.00 exclusive of interest, attorney fees and costs
actual damages for FDUTPA violation
lost monies paid to defendant for counseling services
statutory: damages under Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act (FDUTPA)
equitable: injunction enjoining future violations of FDUTPA
declaratory judgment that defendant violated FDUTPA
other: trial by jury on all issues
such other relief that the Court deems just and proper
attorney's fees and costs under F.S. 501.211(2) and 501.2105

raw_texts: COUNT III- ACTION FOR CONSTRUCTIVE FRAUD OR FRAUD IN THE CONCEALMENT

compensatory: Money paid for counseling sessions ($60 per session for ~2 years)
Pain and suffering
Damages for privacy violation
Damages from ongoing paternity action defense
Compensatory damages (unspecified amount)
Actual damages under FDUTPA
Mental anguish damages
equitable: Declaratory judgment that defendant violated FDUTPA
Injunction enjoining future violations of FDUTPA
other: Such other relief as the Court deems proper

raw_texts: COUNT IV-ACTION FOR VIOLATION OF THE FLA. DECEPTIVE AND UNFAIR TRADE PRACTICES ACT, SECTION 501.204

compensatory: actual damages under FDUTPA
damages greater than $15,000.00
monetary damages under FDUTPA
statutory: damages under Florida Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act (FDUTPA)
equitable: declaratory judgment that defendant violated FDUTPA
injunction enjoining future violations of FDUTPA
other: such other relief that the Court deems just and proper
attorney's fees and costs pursuant to F.S. 501.211(2) and 501.2105
